tasks.title: Find an additional job or source of income
tasks.description: An additional job is an investment in yourself. It can help you to earn more money, gain experience in your field and learn new skills.

steps.text: Start by deciding what you want to do and what you are able to do. Which days and hours of the week are you available to work? Can you work in an office or do you need to work remotely? Are you willing to travel? How far?

Find your local American Job Center (also called OneStop centers or Career One Stop centers). Here is an online database to find one near you: https://www.careeronestop.org/localhelp/find-american-job-centers.aspx
steps.note: If you know the local center, this is where you can add the specific website instead of this national website.

steps.text: Go to the website of your local center and sign up for their email list and/or mailing list to receive updates on job opportunities.
If possible, visit your local center in person and review the bulletin board for job opportunities.
Cast a wide net. Let friends, family, and professional contacts know that you are looking for additional work.
Be sure to review and revise your resume in case it is required for any jobs. Your local center may have help with this too.

If you are interested in starting your own business, SCORE is a national nonprofit that provides free business workshops and individual mentoring. You can find the nearest SCORE center here: https://www.score.org/
steps.note: If you know the local center, this is where you can add the specific website instead of this national website.

tasks.title: Find and enroll in a training or certification program
tasks.description: Free or low-cost training programs can help you earn a certification or degree that can lead to a higher income, more employment opportunities, and work that you enjoy.

steps.text: Find your local American Job Center (also called OneStop centers or Career One Stop centers). Here is an online database to find one near you: https://www.careeronestop.org/localhelp/find-american-job-centers.aspx
steps.note: If you know the local center, this is where you can add the specific website instead of this national website.

steps.text: Go to the website of your local center and sign up for their email list and/or mailing list to receive updates on programs.
Explore your local center’s website for programs, job fairs, training fairs, career workshops, and orientation dates.

Attend an orientation or fair and note the programs that you are eligible for and are interested in. Most events take place during the day, so if you are unable to attend, contact the center and request that the information is mailed to you.

Finally, select the training or certification program in which you’d like to enroll. And don’t hesitate to request a one-on-one with a career coach if you prefer personal assistance in choosing a program.

tasks.title: Ask to increase your hours at work
tasks.description: If you want or need extra income, you might be able to get it from your current employment.

steps.text: Schedule a time to speak with your manager, or ask to speak to them privately if you see that they are available.

Here is a sample script you can use: "I have really enjoyed working here, and I want to thank you for the opportunity. I was wondering if there is any possibility of increasing my hours. If there is a need, I would love to offer my time."
Other possible ways to increase your hours can be offering to work extra shifts, volunteering for difficult to fill shifts, or filling in for people when they are sick or on vacation.

tasks.title: Ask for a raise at work
tasks.description: If you want or need more income, you might be able to get it from current employment.

steps.text: Read the employee handbook to learn about the process of getting a raise at your company.
Schedule a time to speak with your manager, or once you see that they are available ask if they can speak privately.

Here is a sample script you can use: "I have really enjoyed working here, and I want to thank you for the opportunity. I've grown and accomplished a lot since I started working here. [List 3 lessons and/or accomplishments.] Given that I'm responsible for [list responsibilities] and have been with the company for [list time], I would like to see if there is a possibility for me to get a raise."

tasks.title: Have other household members start contributing to household expenses
tasks.description: If you want or need more income, you might be able to get it from other household members.

steps.text: Discuss values/experiences/fears/goals around money with your other household members.
Complete a household budget with your other household members.
Identify a collective savings goal and the individual contributions needed to achieve that goal.
Monitor household expenses together for a week or month and determine if/how the current household income is sufficient to meet those expenses.
Identify times in the month when expenses are high and why.
Brainstorm with your other household members additional ways to earn income.

tasks.title: Take in a renter, roommate, or boarder to help with the cost of rent
tasks.description: If you want or need more income to cover the cost of rent, consider taking in a renter, roommate or boarder.

steps.text: Identify a room/space in your apartment or home that is available to rent.
Research the cost of other rentals in your geographic location to determine the price of your available space.
Create flyers, website listings, etc. to advertise the room/space for rent.

tasks.title: Talk with your partner about finding a job or additional source of income
tasks.description: If you want or need more income, you may be able to get it from a partner if they begin earning additional income.

steps.text: Discuss values/experiences/fears/goals around money with your partner.
Work out a household budget with them.
Track household expenses for a week or month with your partner.
Identify a common savings goal and the steps required to achieve that goal with your partner.
Discuss their interests in earning additional income to support the household.
Find job/career readiness workshops and one-on-one support through organizations such as United Way to assist your partner in updating their resume and submitting job applications.

tasks.title: Contact child support enforcement to collect on unpaid child support
tasks.description: If you are not married to the father/mother of your child, collecting unpaid child support can support you in meeting your household expenses and other financial goals.

steps.text: Establish parenthood (if not voluntarily acknowledged).

Be sure to contact your local child support office to learn more about the application process which varies by state: https://www.acf.hhs.gov/css/parents/how-do-you-get-child-support/applying-for-child-support
Ask your child support office how a child support order is enforced.

tasks.title: Contact your utility company and ask for Budget Billing in order to lower monthly payments
tasks.description: Enrolling in Budget Billing with your utility company will make your monthly payments predictable. With Budget Billing, your monthly payment will be the average of your last 12 months of energy and electricty usage. Typically with this service, you pay less during the winter months, and more during the summer months.

steps.text: Call your utility company and ask if they have Budget Billing as an option.

If they do and you qualify, enroll over the phone. It is important to note that you may either owe money or get a refund of the account balance at the end of the year depending on whether or not the Budget Billing amounts were an accurate estimate of your actual usage.

tasks.title: Explore lower cost cell phone plans
tasks.description: Shop around a bit to see if you can lower your phone bill.

steps.text: Review your current phone statement to see which services you are actually using from your cell phone plan.
steps.note: If you know the local center, this is where you can add the specific website instead of this national website.

steps.text: Cancel or reduce any services that you are not using. Some of these may be a landline, caller ID, call waiting, large data or packages.

If you need additional services, such as long distance calling, consider adding an unlimited long distance calling package to your cell phone plan. It may cost less than individual calls. Also consider using a free online service such as Skype, Google Hangouts, or Zoom.
LifeLine is government assistance for phone or internet. You can find out if you qualify here: https://www.lifelinesupport.org/ls/do-i-qualify/default.aspx
steps.note: If you can check the client's eligibility for LifeLine for them, edit this step accordingly.

steps.text: If you do qualify for LifeLine, follow the steps listed here to apply: https://www.lifelinesupport.org/ls/apply-for-lifeline/default.aspx.
If you do not qualify for LifeLine, compare other cell phone plans in your area using this online tool called WhistleOut: https://www.whistleout.com/CellPhones
If friends or family have cell phone plans, ask if you can join under a family plan, and split the costs.

tasks.title: Track income and spending for one month
tasks.description: Knowledge is power. It is the same with your finances. When you know how much money you have coming in and going out, and where it's going, you are able to make better choices. You have more information to decide what to do with money left after expenses, whether certain expenses need to be cut, or if you need to consider additional income to meet your goals. Find a tool that is easy and enjoyable enough to use regularly.

steps.text:
If you want to use a computer or mobile device and link your accounts online, try: Mint, Personal Capital, or You Need a Budget (free for 34 days then $6.99/month). Link your online accounts (checking, savings, credit cards, student loans, etc.) to the app. The app will automatically categorize income and expenses. The app may let you manually enter expenses you paid for in cash.
OR
If you want to use a computer or mobile device and manually enter transactions (and not link accounts online), try: Dollarbird, Goodbudget, Google sheets, Excel, or any note-taking tool. Search online for a expense tracking template, or create your own.
OR
If you want to use paper and pencil, start a tracking notebook or list. Search online for a expense tracking template, or create your own.
steps.note: If you have a tracking tool you would recommend to the client, add it here.

steps.text: Set an alarm to check the app regularly and see if the expense categories are correct. Make edits if necessary.
After one month, review your income and expenses. Ask yourself if there are any expenses you can cut or lower. Also, determine if you need or want to earn more income.

tasks.title: Create a list of ideas on how you can reduce expenses for your household
tasks.description: Knowing how much money is coming in and out (and where it's going) is power. With this knowledge, you can identify what expenses you/your household can reduce.

steps.text: Monitor all expenses for a week or a month to determine how much money is spent by you or those in your household.

Identify the expenses that can be lowered or eliminated. If the goal is to reduce food expenses, for example, consider meal prepping and packing lunches instead of buying out. Perhaps use coupons or buy in bulk for regularly purchased items.
Discuss the pros and cons of cutting back on certain expenses as a household.
Ask each member of the household to establish at least one goal related to reducing expenses. Come up with a fun way to measure progress towards that goal.
Identify ways to celebrate your household's goals around reducing expenses. Cook a meal together, have a movie or game night. Make less spending enjoyable.

tasks.title: Apply for local housing assistance
tasks.description: Housing assistance programs can support you in finding an affordable home, or help achieve your other financial goals.

steps.text: Contact a public housing agency by visiting: https://www.hud.gov/topics/rental_assistance)

tasks.title: Review cable plan and explore lower cost options
tasks.description: If you want to reduce your cable expenses, consider the following strategies.

steps.text: Review your cable bill, then your overall budget to identify the amount you can reasonably afford to pay for cable.
Identify extra features or channels (such as HBO, Showtime, DVR, etc.) that you can eliminate.
Research smaller cable packages (e.g. one with fewer channels).
Explore opportunities to bundle your services (e.g. phone, internet and cable) with your current provider to save costs.
Explore other service providers and promotions in your area. Inquire about possible cancellation fees you would have to incur to change providers.
Contact your cable provider and negotiate the cost of your service.
If none of these options work, cancel your cable service or identify ways to reduce other expenses so that you are able to afford your cable costs.

tasks.title: Apply for local energy assistance program(s)
tasks.description: Local energy assistance programs can help you reduce your heating and cooling costs, moving you closer to your ultimate financial goals.

steps.text: Visit the following link to find out if you qualify for The Low Income Home Energy Assistance Programs: https://www.benefits.gov/benefits/benefit-details/623
Submit an application for the programs you qualify for here: https://www.acf.hhs.gov/ocs/liheap-state-and-territory-contact-listing

tasks.title: Look into refinancing car loan
tasks.description: If you want to reduce your car payment expenses, consider the following strategies.

steps.text: Review your most recent statement to get a clear understanding of your current auto loan. Pinpoint your monthly payment, interest, remaining balance, loan term, etc.
Order a free credit report to ensure that all of your car payments have been reported correctly. Also check to make sure that you don't have any outstanding items.

Research car loan and refinancing options in your area and apply to those that interest you. Submit applications within a 15-day period to control the amount of points your credit score will drop as a result of inquiries that will be conducted.

If you're approved, assess the amount of money you will save (if any) by refinancing your car (https://www.nerdwallet.com/blog/loans/auto-loans/refinance-calculator-2/) and determine if refinancing is your best option.
If you choose to move forward with refinancing your car, decide between keeping your existing loan term or shortening/lengthening it. Then submit an application with the new lender.

tasks.title: Find a home with lower rent
tasks.description: If you want to reduce your housing costs, consider the following strategies.

steps.text: Identify the amount you can reasonably afford to pay for rent.
Explore affordable renting options in your area here: https://www.usa.gov/finding-home)
Conduct apartment/housing research in your area.

tasks.title: Complete your tax return for free with your local VITA (Volunteer Income Tax Assistance) free tax prep site
tasks.description: Get your taxes done for free at your local VITA free tax prep site. Use the money you save, along with what you receive in a refund, to assist in your financial goals.

steps.text: Find VITA sites in your area by visiting: https://irs.treasury.gov/freetaxprep/

tasks.title: Lower food costs. Get food from a Share Food Network to supplement paying for groceries, or look into food pantries (www.foodpantries.org)
tasks.description: Lower food costs.

tasks.title: Access and download your credit report online from all three credit bureaus
tasks.description: Whether it's to improve your credit score or to simply monitor your report to ensure that all information is accurate, you should request a copy of your credit report at least once a year.

steps.text: Go to www.annualcreditreport.com and click "Request your free credit reports." Request a credit report from each of the bureaus: Transunion, Equifax, and Experian.
Download or save each credit report as a PDF.

tasks.title: Request one credit report by mail from each of the three credit bureaus
tasks.description: Whether it's to improve your credit score or to simply monitor your report to ensure that all information is accurate, you should request a copy of your credit report at least once a year.

steps.text: Complete, print, and mail the following form to the address provided on the site: https://www.annualcreditreport.com/manualRequestForm.action
You should receive your credit reports in the mail within 2-3 weeks.

tasks.title: Review your credit report(s)
tasks.description: Reviewing your credit report is the first step in improving or maintaining your credit history and score. It's also important to review your credit report regularly to ensure that the information is accurate.

steps.text: Review the personal information, credit history, inquiries, and public records sections of your credit report. Here's some help to understand each section: https://www.experian.com/blogs/ask-experian/how-to-read-an-experian-credit-report/.
As you review the report, take notes on any possible errors and write down any questions you may have.

If there are any errors, consider disputing the error through the credit bureau(s). You can do this online or by mailing in a dispute letter. Here are instructions: https://www.consumer.ftc.gov/articles/0151-disputing-errors-credit-reports.
steps.note: If your organization has its own resources for disputing credit report errors, this is where you can share those with the client.

steps.text: If you find any accounts in collections or see any infromation that you would like to dispute, contact a pro bono (free) consumer debt attorney for assistance: https://www.lawhelp.org/find-help/.
steps.note: If you know the local referral, this is where you can add the specific website instead of this national website.

steps.text: If you would like help reviewing your credit reports, schedule a meeting with your financial coach.
steps.note: If you have a scheduling link, this is where you can add one for the client to make an appointment with a financial coach.

tasks.title: Dispute errors on credit reports
tasks.description: Disputing errors on credit reports can help you clean up your credit report and increase your credit score.

steps.text: Go to www.annualcreditreport.come and click "Request your free credit reports." Enter your personal information and request one credit report from Transunion, Equifax and Experian.
Download and save each credit report as a PDF file or print each credit report for your reference.

If there are any errors, consider disputing the error through the credit bureau(s). You can do this online or by mailing in a dispute letter. Here are instructions: https://www.consumer.ftc.gov/articles/0151-disputing-errors-credit-reports.
If you find any accounts in collections or see any infromation that you would like to dispute, contact a pro bono (free) consumer debt attorney for assistance: https://www.lawhelp.org/find-help/.

tasks.title: Make on-time payments on all active lines of credit
tasks.description: Making on-time payments on all active lines of credit will help you maintain or increase your credit score and establish a positive credit history.

steps.text: Create a list of all active credit lines and their payment due dates.
Assess if these due dates are compatible with the times you receive your income(s). If not, contact your creditors to negotiate payment dates.
Find a way to keep track of your payment dates (such as calendar reminders) or consider automatic payment options.

tasks.title: Explore entering into an income-based student loan repayment plan for your federal student loans
tasks.description: Altering your student loan repayment plan options to meet your current financial circumstances can support you in paying back your debt (and keep your credit score up) while not incurring other financial difficulties.

steps.text: FInd out if you qualify for income-based student loan repayment options here: http://www.ibrinfo.org/can.vp.html
Visit this link to submit an application to alter your student loan repayment plan: https://studentloans.gov/myDirectLoan/index.action

tasks.title: Create a debt repayment plan
tasks.description: If you have the means to put some of your income toward your debt, the following steps can help you prioritize the allocation of those funds to become debt-free faster.

steps.text: List all of your debts. For each debt, include the lender, balance, minimum payment, interest rate, and monthly due date.

If your credit score has improved since you've opened your credit cards, try asking for a lower Annual Percentage Rate (APR) on each of your credit cards. This could reduce your monthly payments and the total amount of interest you will pay for credit card debt. Here is a script for negotiating interest rates on credit cards: http://www.creditcards.com/credit-card-news/script-negotiate-better-credit-card-deal-1267.php

List all income and expenses (including minimum monthly debt payments), and determine how much you have available every month to pay toward your debt. List all savings and decide how much you would like to contribute toward paying down your debt. Tip: Prioritize payments toward the highest interest rate debts.

For debts that are credit cards, personal loans, auto loans, home loans, and private student loans, enter information into a debt repayment calculator to calculate when the debt will be paid off under your current repayment schedule. A free online tool is www.powerpay.org. You can change the repayment plan and see how quickly your debt will be paid off with extra payments.

For federal student loan debts, log into the Repayment Estimator (https://studentloans.gov/myDirectLoan/mobile/repayment/repaymentEstimator.action) to find the best repayment plan for you. You may be eligible for an income-driven repayment plan, based on your adjusted gross income, state, and household size.
steps.note: Include here a free local student loan counseling service that accepts referrals, such as American Student Assistance (www.asa.org).

steps.text: For federal tax debt, find a Low-Income Tax Clinic, to access pro bono (free) attorneys who may be able to help you lower the debt or enter into a repayment plan that works for you. You can find a LITC near you here: https://taxpayeradvocate.irs.gov/about/litc

For collection or judgment accounts, seek a pro bono (free) consumer debt attorney for assistance: https://www.lawhelp.org/find-help/. They may also advise on whether or not you would be a candidate for bankruptcy.
Adjust your monthly income and expenses list, and include any minimum and extra payments toward debt as an expense. If possible, set automatic extra payments toward debts.

If you would like help creating a debt repayment plan, here are three options:
Schedule a meeting with your financial coach.
OR
Talk to a credit counselor. The National Federation of Credit Counselors (NFCC) agency assists borrowers who are having difficulty paying their debt. If you can't pay your bills on time consistently each month, then you may want to get personalized advice from a counselor. Talk to a counselor to understand what your options are. There may be a fee for these services. You can find an NFCC member agency here: https://www.nfcc.org/
OR
Visit a local credit union, ideally a Community Development Credit Union. You may be able to refinance credit card debt, auto loans, or other consumer debt, into loans with lower interest rates at a credit union. This could save you money on interest payments each month and make more room in your budget. Some CDCUs also offer financial counseling to help you reach your financial goals. You can find your nearest CDCU here: http://www.cdcu.coop/membership/membership-directory/
steps.note: For scheduling, insert a scheduling link for the client to make an appointment with a financial coach. Or if your organization refers out for this type of support, include the referral here. If you know any local providers that would be better, insert them here.

tasks.title: Consider enrolling in a debt management plan
tasks.description: If you are having difficulty making minimum payments on your debts, a debt management program (DMP) may help you get out of debt faster. They will work with you to decrease your interest rates and create a repayment plan to get out of debt within 3-5 years. There will be an initial fee and monthly fee to remain in the DMP. Avoid "debt settlement" companies.

steps.text: Any DMP will require you to close almost all of your credit card accounts. Decide if you are willing to do that.
Find a reputable DMP using this online search tool: https://www.justice.gov/ust/list-credit-counseling-agencies-approved-pursuant-11-usc-111.
steps.note: If you know the local referral, this is where you can add the specific website instead of this national website.

steps.text: List all of your debts. For each debt, include the lender, balance, minimum payment, interest rate, and monthly due date. You will need this information before you start working with the DMP.

List all income and expenses (including minimum monthly debt payments), and determine how much you have available every month to pay toward your debt. List all savings and decide how much you would like to contribute toward paying down debt. You will need this information before you start working with the DMP.
Call the DMP for your initial session. They will review your budget and debts to determine if you can benefit from a DMP.
If you decide to enroll, negotiate any hardship discounts to decrease the initial or monthly fees for enrolling in the DMP.
